title: Global-e Online Shares Slip After Guidance Cut, Analyst Moves

contentObject.content: Shares of Global-e Online Ltd. moved lower in early trading on Tuesday after the cross-border e-commerce platform cut its revenue guidance, prompting a raft of Wall Street analysts to reduce their price targets.

The Petah Tikva, Israel, company said it now expects full-year revenue of $383 million to $403 million, down from a prior forecast of $411 million to $421 million, citing recent trends that include the impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and macro environment headwinds on consumption, mainly in Europe.
In a research note, analysts at Piper Sandler said they cut their price target on Global-e shares to $30 from $58 due to revised estimates that factor in the near-term consumer headwinds.

However, Piper Sandler kept its "overweight" rating on the stock, saying it maintains a favorable view on Global-e because the company generates positive free cash flow and is "well poised to outgrow the commerce industry."
Analysts at Keybanc, Needham, JMP Securities and Raymond James similarly reduced their price targets on Global-e shares but maintained favorable ratings on the stock.
Global-e shares were recently changing hands at $17.55, down 8.6%.
Write to Colin Kellaher at colin.kellaher@wsj.com
